metadata.titleEn: Future permafrost distribution over the Qinghai‐Tibet Plateau under different SSP scenarios (2016-2100)
metadata.description: The Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, known as the "Third Pole", and the permafrost distribution map is of great significance for engineering construction, ecological and hydrological research in the cold region. This dataset is based on the output data of the climate models participating in CMIP6, and after statistical downscaling, it is simulated and generated using the improved Noah land surface process model. This dataset provides the distribution map of permafrost on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau in the future for five GCMs (BCC-CSM2-MR, CESM2, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR and MRI-ESM2-0) under different shared socioeconomic pathway (SSP) scenarios (including SSP1-2.6 , SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5). The time range is 2016-2100, the time resolution is a year, the spatial resolution is 0.1°, the data format is TIFF, DN=1 represents permafrost, and DN=2 represents non-permafrost. This dataset can be used as a primary source of data for research on permafrost, ecology, hydrology, and other topics in the third polar region.

background: As a unique geomorphological unit on Earth, the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) is sensitive to global warming, and has warmed twice as fast as the global average over the past five decades. The QTP, known as the “Third Pole,” has the largest area of alpine permafrost in the world. Permafrost on the QTP has been observed to have degraded substantially as a result of drastic climate warming, as evidenced by increasing ground temperature, thickening of the active layer, and continued decline. Global warming has led to permafrost degradation worldwide. The Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) hosts most of the world's alpine permafrost, yet its impending changes remain largely unclear, thereby affecting regional hydrological and ecological processes and the global carbon budget. Existing prediction studies have consistently concluded that QTP permafrost will degrade with climate warming, but there is no consensus on the extent of degradation.
research objective: To date, there have been no studies employing land surface models to predict future changes in QTP permafrost based on the latest Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 data. Here, based on climate outputs from multi-model projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways, we used a land surface model adapted to frozen ground modeling to simulate future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the QTP, and evaluated permafrost responses to various scenarios of future climate change.
challenges: To the best of current knowledge, these permafrost projections have several weaknesses. Previous projections are generally limited to changes in permafrost area and rarely consider changes in permafrost thermal regimes, such as those represented by mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) and active layer thickness (ALT). Most projections are based on empirical/statistical models, but such models are often data-driven and suffer from poor transferability of model parameters when applied to long-term simulations, which generally makes them unsuitable for future projections. Despite the fact that a few studies have used process-based physical models that account for water and heat exchange processes between the atmosphere and the ground, as well as local factors such as vegetation, snow cover, soil type, and moisture conditions, these models have not been specifically developed to simulate frozen ground dynamics. Most projections are based on single atmospheric driving data or simple warming scenarios, thus projection results may contain larger uncertainties stemming from the uncertainties associated with these datasets and the models that generate them. Moreover, existing predictions generally neglect the effects of climate wetting, whereas our recent study showed that climate wetting on the QTP mitigates warming-induced permafrost degradation under a warm-wet climate.
methods: In this work, based on historical and downscaled future forcings from the projections under the different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs), that is, SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5, which are the most commonly used in CMIP6, we first employed the modified Noah LSM to simulate future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the QTP at a spatial resolution of 0.1°. Second, we evaluated permafrost responses to various future climate changes by comparing the results simulated under different combinations of GCMs and SSPs. Finally, in order to obtain intuitive sense of how permafrost responds to climate warming on the QTP, we examined the sensitivity of permafrost to climate warming on the basis of simulated changes in permafrost and corresponding projected air temperatures from five GCMs projections under different SSPs.
dataset: The data used in this study include a regional reanalysis data, and climate outputs of five GCMs participating in CMIP6. The reanalysis data set is the China Meteorological Forcing Data set (CMFD), which contains seven atmospheric variables for the period 1979–2018 with a 3-hr time step and a 0.1° spatial resolution. The climate projection data chosen are the outputs of five GCMs with well-resolved resolution (BCC-CSM2-MR, CESM2, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, and MRI-ESM2-0) to better characterize the spatial differentiation of climate forcing on a regional scale, particularly in regions with high topography, such as the QTP.
findings: Projections for SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5 show that most of the continuous permafrost region of the QTP will persist through 2050. Much of the permafrost is likely to degrade in the late 21st century, with projected area losses of 44 ± 4%, 59 ± 5%, and 71 ± 7%, respectively, by 2100. The mean annual ground temperature of QTP permafrost will increase by 0.8 ± 0.2°C, 2.0 ± 0.3°C, and 2.6 ± 0.3°C under SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5, respectively, and the active layer thickness will increase by 0.7 ± 0.1 m, 1.5 ± 0.3 m, and 3.0 ± 1.0 m, respectively. The surviving permafrost under SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5 will be thermally unstable, which is a clear warning sign of complete disappearance. The analysis of permafrost sensitivity to climate change signifies that alpine permafrost on the QTP has low resilience to climate change, in contrast to permafrost in pan-Arctic high latitudes.

Definition.Question: What challenges arise from using empirical models for projecting permafrost degradation?
Definition.Answer: Empirical models for projecting permafrost degradation face challenges such as poor transferability of model parameters when applied to long-term simulations. These models are typically data-driven and may not accurately project future changes due to their reliance on historical data, making them less suitable for future predictions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using CMIP6 climate models compare to traditional empirical models in terms of predicting permafrost changes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: CMIP6 climate models, used in conjunction with a modified Noah land surface model, provide a more process-based approach that considers atmospheric and ground interactions, unlike traditional empirical models that are primarily data-driven and may lack transferability for long-term simulations.

Interpretation.Question: How do the underlying data collection methods, such as reanalysis datasets and climate projections, influence our understanding of permafrost thermal regimes and their changes?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection methods, including the use of regional reanalysis datasets like the CMFD and climate projections from GCMs, offer detailed insights into permafrost thermal regimes by providing high-resolution climate forcings. These methods enable the modeling of permafrost distribution and thermal responses to projected climate changes, thereby enhancing understanding.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with using land surface models for predicting future permafrost changes, and how might these challenges affect interpretation of the data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges with using land surface models include limited consideration of changes in thermal regimes, poor transferability of empirical models, and uncertainties in atmospheric driving data. These challenges may affect data interpretation by introducing uncertainties in projections, especially regarding the extent and thermal stability of permafrost degradation under different climate scenarios.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes for the lack of consensus on permafrost degradation extent in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of consensus on the extent of permafrost degradation in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is primarily due to the use of empirical/statistical models, which are often data-driven and suffer from poor transferability when applied to long-term simulations. Additionally, most projections are based on single atmospheric driving data or simple warming scenarios, leading to larger uncertainties. The neglect of climate wetting effects in existing predictions also contributes to the discrepancies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do existing permafrost projections often fail to consider changes in thermal regimes such as mean annual ground temperature and active layer thickness?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Existing permafrost projections often fail to consider changes in thermal regimes because they generally rely on empirical/statistical models that focus mainly on changes in permafrost area. Such models do not adequately account for the physical processes involved, such as water and heat exchange between the atmosphere and the ground, which are necessary to accurately simulate changes in thermal regimes like mean annual ground temperature and active layer thickness.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons for the large uncertainties in projection results of permafrost degradation on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary reasons for the large uncertainties in projection results of permafrost degradation on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau stem from reliance on single atmospheric driving data or simple warming scenarios. Additionally, the lack of specifically developed process-based physical models to simulate frozen ground dynamics and the neglect of climate wetting effects further contribute to these uncertainties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of neglecting climate wetting effects in permafrost degradation projections on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Neglecting climate wetting effects in permafrost degradation projections may lead to overestimated rates of permafrost degradation on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Recent studies have shown that climate wetting can mitigate warming-induced permafrost degradation under a warm-wet climate, suggesting that projections which ignore this factor could present an incomplete picture of future permafrost stability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of using a land surface model adapted to frozen ground modeling in predicting future changes in permafrost distribution on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to simulate future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using climate outputs from multi-model projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways, and to evaluate permafrost responses to various scenarios of future climate change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind examining the sensitivity of permafrost to climate warming on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to obtain an intuitive sense of how permafrost responds to climate warming on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and to analyze the sensitivity of permafrost to climate change by simulating changes in permafrost and corresponding projected air temperatures from five GCMs projections under different SSPs.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to simulate future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using climate model outputs?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The simulation of future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau involves using a land surface model, specifically the modified Noah LSM, with downscaled future forcings from climate model projections under different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs). The process includes evaluating permafrost responses to various climate change scenarios by comparing results simulated under different combinations of General Circulation Models (GCMs) and SSPs. The spatial resolution employed in the simulation is 0.1°.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the spatial differentiation of climate forcing characterized in regions with high topography like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using the available datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The spatial differentiation of climate forcing in high topography regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is characterized using climate projection data from five General Circulation Models (GCMs) with well-resolved resolution. These models include BCC-CSM2-MR, CESM2, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, and MRI-ESM2-0, which help in better capturing the spatial differentiation of climate forcing on a regional scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are necessary to address the uncertainties associated with empirical/statistical models when projecting permafrost degradation in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address uncertainties in empirical/statistical models when projecting permafrost degradation, it is necessary to incorporate process-based physical models that account for water and heat exchange processes between the atmosphere and the ground, as well as local factors such as vegetation, snow cover, soil type, and moisture conditions. Additionally, using a combination of different atmospheric driving data and considering the effects of climate wetting can help reduce uncertainties and improve the accuracy of future projections.

Enablement.Question: What climate models or tools enable the simulation of permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau under various future climate scenarios?
Enablement.Answer: The modified Noah Land Surface Model (LSM) is used to simulate future changes in permafrost distribution and its thermal regimes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, with climate outputs from five GCMs participating in CMIP6 under different SSP scenarios.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of regional reanalysis data contribute to the understanding and prediction of permafrost changes in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The regional reanalysis data, specifically the China Meteorological Forcing Data set (CMFD), provides high-resolution atmospheric variables, which are crucial for characterizing climate forcing and improving the spatial differentiation of projections in regions with high topography like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enhance the transferability and accuracy of long-term permafrost projection models in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of process-based physical models that account for water and heat exchange processes, along with local factors such as vegetation, snow cover, soil type, and moisture conditions, enhances the transferability and accuracy of long-term permafrost projections, although these models still face challenges in simulating frozen ground dynamics accurately.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately projecting changes in permafrost thermal regimes using available datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Existing datasets often rely on empirical/statistical models that may have poor transferability of model parameters for long-term simulations, making them unsuitable for future projections. Additionally, most projections focus on permafrost area changes and overlook thermal regimes such as mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) and active layer thickness (ALT).

Expectation.Question: Why could the use of multiple GCMs and SSP scenarios be necessary for understanding future permafrost changes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Using multiple GCMs and SSP scenarios allows for a more comprehensive evaluation of permafrost responses to various future climate changes and helps to account for uncertainties associated with different climate models. This approach provides insights into the sensitivity of permafrost to climate warming by comparing results under different combinations of GCMs and SSPs.

Expectation.Question: Why might regional reanalysis data be crucial for simulating changes in permafrost distribution on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Regional reanalysis data, such as the China Meteorological Forcing Data set (CMFD), offer high-resolution atmospheric variables that are essential for capturing the spatial differentiation of climate forcing on a regional scale. This is particularly important in regions with high topography like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, where localized climate conditions significantly impact permafrost dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using land surface models for simulating future permafrost changes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges include limitations in previous projections which often focus solely on permafrost area changes without considering thermal regimes. Empirical/statistical models may suffer from poor transferability for long-term simulations. Process-based physical models are better at accounting for exchanges between the atmosphere and ground, but they have not been specifically developed for frozen ground dynamics. Additionally, existing predictions often neglect the effects of climate wetting, which can mitigate warming-induced permafrost degradation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges that arise when using land surface models for simulating permafrost distribution on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the limitations of empirical/statistical models in capturing changes in permafrost thermal regimes, such as mean annual ground temperature and active layer thickness. There's also the issue of poor transferability of model parameters for long-term simulations, and uncertainties in projection results due to reliance on single atmospheric driving data and simple warming scenarios.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the significance of using different GCMs in climate projections for studying permafrost on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Using different GCMs helps to better characterize spatial differentiation of climate forcing on a regional scale, especially in areas with high topography like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. This approach allows for a more nuanced understanding of permafrost responses to various climate change scenarios, reducing uncertainties associated with single-model projections.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of using land surface models (LSMs) for predicting permafrost distribution changes under different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) compared to empirical/statistical models.
Request/Directive.Answer: The use of land surface models (LSMs) adapted for frozen ground modeling is a novel approach for predicting permafrost distribution changes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. LSMs provide a more comprehensive representation of physical processes, such as water and heat exchange, compared to empirical/statistical models, which are often data-driven and limited in their transferability for long-term projections. While empirical models primarily predict changes in permafrost area, LSMs can simulate thermal regimes, including mean annual ground temperature and active layer thickness, offering deeper insights into permafrost dynamics under various SSP scenarios.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges associated with data collection for permafrost modeling on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, focusing on uncertainties in climate forcing datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in data collection for permafrost modeling on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is the uncertainty associated with climate forcing datasets. Most projections rely on single atmospheric driving data or simple warming scenarios, which may lead to larger uncertainties in results due to the variability in models and datasets. The challenge is compounded by the high topography of the region, which requires high-resolution climate data to accurately capture spatial differentiation. Moreover, existing projections often overlook the impact of climate wetting, which can mitigate warming-induced permafrost degradation, adding another layer of complexity to data collection efforts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets used in permafrost modeling on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, with an emphasis on improving spatial resolution and incorporating climate wetting effects.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand or refine datasets for permafrost modeling on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, researchers can focus on improving spatial resolution and incorporating climate wetting effects. Employing high-resolution climate output from Global Climate Models (GCMs) with well-resolved spatial differentiation can better capture the detailed climate forcing in regions with high topography. Additionally, integrating observations from regional reanalysis datasets, such as the China Meteorological Forcing Data set, can provide finer temporal and spatial resolution inputs. Furthermore, considering the effects of climate wetting in model simulations can enhance the accuracy of predictions related to permafrost degradation under different SSP scenarios.
